1.sources: Sharp (How Brands Grow), Romaniuk (Building Distinctive Brand Assets), Ehrenberg-Bass Institute, Barden (Decoded), Keller (Strategic Brand Management), Brand Salience Research
1.brief:
Mental availability is defined by Romaniuk and Sharp as 'the probability that a buyer will notice, recognize and/or think of a brand in buying situations' dependent on 'the quality and quantity of memory structures related to the brand.' Mental availability ensures your brand is recalled in relevant buying moments, not just recognized. As the Ehrenberg-Bass Institute research shows, brands grow primarily by increasing their mental availability and physical availability. Brand growth comes from acquiring new and light buyers, and mental availability is the mechanism by which brands become easier to think of and therefore more likely to be chosen.

Sharp explains in How Brands Grow that buyers have a network of information (brand associations) linked to a brand name. For example, McDonald's is associated with hamburgers, yellow arches, and fast food. These networks of associations are what make brands mentally available. Furthermore, maintenance of mental availability requires distinctive brand assets that trigger the brand in memory without needing to see the brand name. Memory is the link between an ad and brand choice, making every advertising impression an opportunity to strengthen or create memory structures.

Brand Salience research confirms that Brand Salience is a function of the quantity and quality of the consumer's memory structures. The more category entry points a brand is linked to, and the stronger those links, the higher its mental availability. Byron Sharp draws an important distinction: attitudes are about evaluating the brand, whereas salience is largely about having a chance of being thought of. This means mental availability is not about being liked more, but about being recalled more readily in buying situations.

Keller's Strategic Brand Management adds that brand recall is critical for service and online brands, where consumers must actively retrieve the brand from memory rather than simply recognizing it on a shelf. Our brain is a lazy organ that has evolved over millions of years to make good choices with as little energy consumption as possible. We operate automatically and use our attention sparingly. In purchasing environments, this leads to 99.99% of all stimuli being filtered out, making strong mental availability the essential prerequisite for brand choice.

2.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Thaler & Sunstein (Nudge), Barden (Decoded), Duke (Thinking in Bets)
2.brief:
Daniel Kahneman describes two systems of thinking: System 1 operates automatically and quickly, with little or no effort and no sense of voluntary control. System 2 allocates attention to the effortful mental activities that demand it, including complex computations. The intuitive System 1 is more influential than your experience tells you, and it is the secret author of many of the choices and judgments you make. Thaler and Sunstein use the terms Automatic System and Reflective System. The Automatic System is associated with the oldest parts of the brain, the parts we share with lizards.

Barden's Decoded provides crucial additional evidence for this framework. Kahneman's model has been supported by many subsequent studies across psychology and neuroscience. Barden explains the implicit system and how the implicit level of decision making is based on robust and accurate findings from decades of research. The autopilot processes every single bit of information that reaches our senses, with a processing capacity of 11 million bits per second. This is the system that handles the vast majority of our daily decisions, including most purchasing behavior.

Annie Duke's Thinking in Bets extends the framework by showing how these systems create predictable errors. We are susceptible to cognitive traps, like assuming causation when there is only a correlation. System 1 automatically generates stories and causal explanations, which System 2 then accepts uncritically unless it has reason to engage in effortful checking. This has profound implications for how consumers interpret marketing messages and brand experiences.

System 1 does X is a shortcut for X occurs automatically. And System 2 is mobilized to do Y is a shortcut for arousal increases, pupils dilate, attention is focused. The two systems do not really exist in the brain or anywhere else, but they are useful fictions for understanding cognition. For marketers, the implication is clear: most brand decisions are made by System 1, so marketing must work at the automatic, intuitive level rather than relying on rational persuasion that engages System 2.

3.sources: Cialdini (Influence), Shotton (The Choice Factory), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing), Eat Your Greens, Sapolsky (Behave)
3.brief:
Robert Cialdini describes social proof as one of the key principles of influence. As he writes, 'We view a behavior as more correct in a given situation to the degree that we see others performing it.' Social proof is most powerful when we are uncertain and when the people we observe are similar to us. Richard Shotton documents that personalizing social proof messages makes them more potent: 'Most guests reuse their towels' produced 44% towel reuse, but 'Most hotel guests in this room reuse their towels' achieved 49% reuse.

Nancy Harhut explains that social proof isn't always about following the crowd: sometimes people think that others actually know more than they do. What someone's family and close friends were doing was more likely to affect their behavior than whether or not they themselves believed social distancing was important. It overrode even their personal convictions on the topic. A study found that 98% of online shoppers consider authentic customer reviews the most important factor in their purchase decisions.

Eat Your Greens adds compelling evidence for the power of social proof in behavior change contexts. We know that consumers are influenced a lot of the time by social proof and norms, and these are very good levers for behaviour change. Consumers use copying and social learning to shape their choices, making social proof not just an influence tactic but a fundamental mechanism of human decision-making. This evolutionary tendency to learn from others explains why social proof is so pervasive and powerful.

Sapolsky's Behave provides biological context: conformity can be great because it is helpful if everyone agrees whether shaking your head up and down means yes or no. Social proof is deeply rooted in our evolved tendency toward conformity, which serves important social functions. However, this same mechanism can lead to harmful herding effects when the crowd is wrong, making it a powerful but double-edged tool for marketers.

4.sources: Kahneman & Tversky (Prospect Theory), Cialdini (Influence), Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing
4.brief:
Kahneman and Tversky's Prospect Theory demonstrates that outcomes which are obtained with certainty are overweighted relative to uncertain outcomes. The value function for gains is concave, while losses are felt more acutely. People will be reluctant to trade what they own, except at a high price, a phenomenon known as the endowment effect, which is driven by loss aversion. This asymmetry between gains and losses is one of the most robust findings in behavioral economics.

Cialdini notes that under conditions of risk and uncertainty, people are intensely motivated to make choices designed to avoid losing something of value, to a much greater extent than choices designed to obtain that thing. This principle extends beyond financial decisions to encompass any valued possession, relationship, or status. The fear of loss is a more powerful motivator than the prospect of equivalent gain.

In Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, the analysis shows that the way choices are presented (framed) and the information processing of receivers affect the way in which decisions are made. If the framing is manipulated, people can be pushed towards particular alternatives. Loss aversion, mental accounting, and risk tolerance all affect the evaluation of prospects. People will be reluctant to trade what they own, except at a high price, demonstrating how loss aversion is behind the endowment effect.

For marketers, the implications are profound. Framing marketing messages around preventing loss rather than achieving gain can significantly increase persuasive impact. Trial periods exploit loss aversion because once consumers possess a product, giving it up feels like a loss. Subscription models leverage the same principle: canceling feels like losing something you already have. Understanding loss aversion transforms pricing strategy, promotional design, and customer retention approaches.

5.topic: The Long and Short of It
5.sources: Binet & Field (The Long and the Short of It, Effectiveness in Context), IPA Databank, LinkedIn B2B Report
5.brief:
Les Binet and Peter Field's meta-analysis of the IPA effectiveness Databank, covering 996 campaigns, 700 brands, and 83 categories over 30 years, reveals that short and long term effects are different. Short term effects are vital but long-term brand building is the main driver of growth and profit. Their research establishes the 60:40 rule: the optimal split is approximately 60% of budget allocated to brand building and 40% to sales activation, delivering maximum efficiency and effectiveness. Brand building takes over as the primary driver of growth from sales activation after six months.

Effectiveness in Context provides crucial sector-specific adjustments to the 60:40 rule through Brand:Activation Balance Guidelines. The optimal ratio varies by category: some sectors require heavier brand investment while others need more activation. This nuance is often missed when the 60:40 rule is applied as a universal formula rather than a starting point for category-specific optimization.

Brands that set their share of voice above their share of market tend to grow, while those that set SOV below SOM tend to shrink. The LinkedIn B2B Report confirms this finding extends to business markets: brands that set SOV above SOM tend to grow. The annualised ESOV efficiency has been increasing, meaning SOV is becoming more important over time, not less. This contradicts the narrative that traditional media metrics are becoming obsolete.

Brand building reduces price sensitivity and increases margins. The movement towards real-time campaign management and its inevitable focus on short-term results means marketing appears to be sleepwalking towards a precipice. Brand building is ultimately more effective because the effects last longer and so accumulate over time. There is an urgent need for long-term metrics to reassert their importance in an era of dashboard-driven, short-term optimization.

6.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Ariely (Predictably Irrational), Dooley (Brainfluence)
6.brief:
Kahneman demonstrates that the anchoring effect is not a laboratory curiosity; it can be just as strong in the real world. In an experiment, real-estate agents assessed the value of a house based on different asking prices. Half saw a substantially higher asking price than the listed price. The agents were significantly influenced by the asking price, yet insisted they were not. Similar or even larger anchoring effects have been observed in numerous studies of estimates and willingness to pay.

As Kahneman notes, arbitrary rationing is an effective marketing ploy: supermarket shoppers in Sioux City, Iowa, bought significantly more Campbell's soup when presented with an anchor number. The study demonstrated that even meaningless numerical limits change purchasing behavior. Shoppers who saw a sign saying 'Limit 12 per customer' bought far more cans than those who saw no limit, despite having no intention of buying that many.

Dooley explains how Ariely discovered that MIT students bid 3x more when primed with a random higher number. If we decide to buy a big-screen television, we may spot one we like for $1,000. We may not buy that item, but according to Ariely that now becomes an anchor price against which other deals are measured. Anchoring effects are easily observed in online trading, where the same item is often offered at different buy now prices.

The anchoring effect works because System 1 generates an initial estimate that System 2 insufficiently adjusts from. Even experts who should know better fall prey to anchoring, as the real-estate agent study demonstrates. This makes anchoring one of the most practically useful behavioral science principles for pricing, negotiation, and marketing communication. Setting the right initial reference point shapes all subsequent evaluation.

7.sources: Binet & Field (The Long and the Short of It, Effectiveness in Context), Nielsen, LinkedIn B2B Report
7.brief:
The share-of-voice model shows that brands that set their share of voice (SOV) above their share of market (SOM) tend to grow, and those that set SOV below SOM tend to shrink. The rate at which a brand grows or shrinks tends to be proportional to its extra share of voice (ESOV), defined as the difference between SOV and SOM. According to Nielsen research, every 10 points of excess SOV can drive approximately 0.5% of extra market share growth.

The share of voice rule has been known for 50 years and holds true today, despite all the enormous changes in the media landscape. This consistency across decades and media environments is remarkable and provides one of the most reliable planning tools available to marketers. The relationship holds across categories, geographies, and media mixes.

From Effectiveness in Context, the bigger the brand, the higher the base rate, meaning big brands can get away with setting share of voice slightly below market share and still maintain equilibrium. But small brands are more dependent on advertising to maintain market share. They need to keep SOV much more in line with SOM if they are to survive. Big brands use advertising to maintain their market share and to boost margins, which is highly profitable.

The LinkedIn B2B Report confirms these dynamics apply to business markets: brands that set SOV above SOM tend to grow. This challenges the common B2B assumption that advertising is less important than in consumer markets. The ESOV model provides a clear, evidence-based framework for setting advertising budgets that neither overspends nor underspends relative to competitive position.

8.brief:
Robert Cialdini establishes reciprocity as a fundamental principle of influence. As he explains, by virtue of the reciprocity rule, we are obligated to the future repayment of favors, gifts, invitations, and the like. So typical is it for indebtedness to accompany the receipt of such things that a term like 'much obliged' has become a synonym for 'thank you.' The rule was established to promote the development of reciprocal relationships between individuals so that one person could initiate such a relationship without the fear of loss.

An uninvited first favor must have the ability to create an obligation. The American Disabled Veterans organization found that its simple mail appeal for donations produces a response rate of about 18 percent. But when the mailing also includes an unsolicited gift (gummed, individualized address labels), the success rate nearly doubles to 35 percent. This demonstrates that even small, unsolicited gifts create powerful feelings of obligation.

Shotton notes that the door-in-the-face technique taps into reciprocity: when someone makes a concession by reducing their request, we feel obligated to reciprocate with a concession of our own. In the control condition, 50% turned up. This figure rose to 85% when the door-in-the-face technique was harnessed. The power of reciprocal concession is remarkable in its consistency across contexts.

For content marketers and B2B professionals, reciprocity provides a clear framework for value creation. By providing genuinely useful content, insights, and tools before asking for anything in return, marketers can create a sense of obligation that makes prospects more receptive to commercial messages. The key is that the initial gift must be perceived as genuine and valuable, not as a transparent manipulation tactic.

9.sources: Thaler & Sunstein (Nudge), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing)
9.brief:
Choice architecture is the practice of influencing choice by organizing the context in which people make decisions. Thaler and Sunstein describe how good choice architecture combines getting rid of bad options and introducing novel ones, while ensuring choices must be designed so as to make the customer journey as frictionless as possible. Status quo bias is easily exploited, and changing the default can be an effective nudge.

Harhut emphasizes that when employing choice architecture, marketers should never force their customers' hands. Customers should always be able to make a different choice than the one you want them to. Research has shown that people's decisions are impacted by the way their options are presented. Removing friction and simplifying options can help people make the choice you hope they do.

Your customers will have a strong preference for the status quo, for the way things are. It might be due to familiarity, loss aversion, time and effort already invested, or habit. Defaults are often perceived to be hints that they are the recommended option. This perception transforms what might seem like a neutral presentation into a powerful influence mechanism.

The practical application of choice architecture extends far beyond simple default setting. It encompasses the ordering of options (primacy and recency effects), the number of options presented (too many leads to choice overload), the visual prominence given to different alternatives, and the labeling and framing of each option. Every aspect of how choices are presented influences the decision, whether the architect intends it or not. The question is not whether to practice choice architecture, but whether to do it well or poorly.

10.sources: Romaniuk (Building Distinctive Brand Assets), Sharp (How Brands Grow), Creativity in Distinctive Brand Assets (Velykyte, 2023), Eat Your Greens, Ehrenberg-Bass Institute
10.brief:
Distinctive brand assets are the non-brand-name elements that identify a brand: colors, logos, mascots, sounds, taglines, and visual styles. Romaniuk's framework measures brand assets on two dimensions: fame (how widely known the asset is) and uniqueness (how exclusively it is associated with one brand). The Distinctive Asset Grid provides a systematic way to measure and manage these assets over time.

Sharp explains in How Brands Grow that without distinctive brand assets it is difficult for consumers to digest a brand's communications. Assets serve as the retrieval cues that link advertising exposure to the brand in memory. If an ad lacks distinctive brand assets, the consumer may enjoy it but fail to connect it to the correct brand, wasting the entire investment. This is why branding is not an afterthought but the central mechanism of advertising effectiveness.

Creative branding involves developing a unique and compelling brand personality that resonates with consumers, expressed through distinctive brand assets. Color is one of the most powerful and recognizable elements of a brand's visual identity. Some of the most famous examples include the Nike Swoosh, the Aflac Duck, and Mastercard's Priceless advertising style, all able to represent the brand without needing the brand name. Legal recognition protects a brand asset's unique identity and makes it possible for it to exist as its own entity.

Eat Your Greens provides a cautionary tale: Tropicana's relaunch failed because it rejected the 'straw in the orange' asset. This iconic visual had built massive fame and uniqueness over decades. When Tropicana replaced it with a generic design, sales dropped 20% in two months, costing an estimated $50 million. The lesson is clear: distinctive brand assets are strategic assets that take years to build and moments to destroy. Research shows logos and mascots typically grow quickly in fame and uniqueness, while other assets develop more slowly.

11.sources: Cialdini (Influence), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing)
11.brief:
Cialdini identifies scarcity as a powerful weapon of influence. The scarcity principle trades on our weakness for shortcuts: because we know that things that are difficult to possess are typically better than those that are easy to get, we can often use availability as a shortcut for quality. This heuristic evolved because scarce resources genuinely were more valuable throughout most of human history.

Harhut breaks scarcity into two sides: urgency and exclusivity. Urgency, expressed through limited quantities and limited times, motivates people to take action. Marketers can employ urgency using deadlines, countdown clocks, and restricted quantities. These time-pressure tactics activate loss aversion, making people fear they will miss out on the opportunity.

In a dramatic example, Cialdini describes a study where beef buyers who were told about future scarcity bought significantly more. Those who also learned the scarcity information was exclusive (the scarcity double whammy) purchased even more. The restriction of information made it both more desirable and more persuasive. As Cialdini notes, the finding was quite straightforward: the value of information was seen to grow if it was scarce.

Not only was the commodity itself seen as more valuable, but the exclusive information about it was valued even more. This double-layered scarcity effect is particularly relevant in the age of content marketing and thought leadership. Exclusive research, proprietary data, and early access to insights all leverage the scarcity principle. The key ethical consideration is that manufactured scarcity without genuine limitation erodes trust when discovered, while authentic scarcity communicated transparently is both effective and ethical.

12.sources: Zajonc (via Dooley, Brainfluence), Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow)
12.brief:
Psychologist Robert Zajonc demonstrated the mere exposure effect by showing non-Chinese-speaking subjects a series of Chinese ideographs. One group received five exposures, the other just one. In all cases, exposures lasted only five milliseconds or less, too fast for conscious recognition. Yet the symbols previously seen were consistently rated more positively. The familiarity had created a positive connotation without any conscious awareness.

In a similar experiment, members of the group with repeated exposure reported being in better moods. The mere exposure effect operates at a pre-conscious level, meaning it works even when people have no memory of having seen the stimulus before. This makes it fundamentally different from persuasion, which requires conscious processing of arguments.

Kahneman connects this to cognitive ease: repetition induces cognitive ease, and things that are cognitively easy feel more familiar and more likable. Stocks with pronounceable trading symbols (like KAR or LUNMOO) outperform those with tongue-twisting tickers like PXG or RDO. A study in Switzerland found that investors believe stocks with fluent names like Emmi and Swissfirst will earn higher returns than those with clunky labels like Geberit and Ypsomed.

The mere exposure effect works with characters, musical tones, and faces alike. For brand building, this provides the scientific foundation for the importance of consistent, repeated brand exposure. It explains why maintaining advertising presence (even at low levels) is more effective than sporadic high-intensity campaigns. Each exposure, even a brief or peripheral one, contributes to the positive association between the consumer and the brand.

13.topic: Q1 Synthesis: The Science of Being Chosen
13.sources: Multiple Q1 sources: Sharp, Kahneman, Cialdini, Binet & Field, Romaniuk, Barden (Decoded), Eat Your Greens, Sapolsky (Behave)
13.brief:
The Q1 research reveals a coherent framework for understanding how brands get chosen. Mental availability (Sharp, Romaniuk) ensures brands come to mind in buying situations, with brand salience being a function of the quantity and quality of memory structures. System 1 processing (Kahneman) means most purchase decisions are automatic and intuitive, not deliberate. Barden's Decoded confirms that the autopilot processes 11 million bits per second, handling the vast majority of consumer decisions.

Social proof (Cialdini) shows people look to others when uncertain, with Eat Your Greens confirming that consumers use copying and social learning to shape their choices. Loss aversion means framing around what could be lost is more powerful than what could be gained. The 60:40 rule (Binet & Field) establishes the optimal balance between brand building and activation, with Effectiveness in Context providing sector-specific adjustments.

Anchoring demonstrates that even arbitrary numbers influence purchasing decisions. The SOV/SOM relationship shows that share of voice drives market share growth, confirmed across both B2C and B2B markets. Reciprocity, choice architecture, distinctive brand assets, scarcity, and mere exposure all operate as System 1 shortcuts that shape brand selection. Sharp's insight that without distinctive brand assets it is difficult for consumers to digest communications underscores the importance of branding consistency.

Together, these principles show that brands don't win by rational persuasion but by building mental availability through consistent, broad-reach advertising that creates positive associations and leverages behavioral biases. The Tropicana case demonstrates the catastrophic cost of ignoring these principles. Annie Duke's work on cognitive traps reminds us that even marketers themselves are susceptible to the same biases they seek to leverage.

Brands grow primarily by increasing their mental availability and physical availability. - Sharp, How Brands Grow

14.sources: Cialdini (Pre-Suasion), Presuasion: The Hidden Forces That Influence Negotiations
14.brief:
Cialdini's Pre-Suasion explores how communicators can pre-suade by focusing recipients initially on concepts that are aligned, associatively, with the information yet to be delivered. The mechanism involves an underappreciated characteristic of mental activity: its elements don't just fire when ready, they fire when connected. Priming an individual before a particular task can assert a certain hidden force upon that individual's selection or decision-making processes. If individuals were truly rational in the traditional sense, then priming should have no effect.

Privileged moments are windows in time when individuals are particularly receptive to a message. The communicator who can fasten an audience's focus onto the favorable elements of an argument raises the likelihood of persuasion. Besides drawing attention to a particular stimulus, there is considerable benefit to holding it there. Naturally occurring commanders of attention include the sexual, the threatening, and the different.

Cialdini provides a striking example of attention overload: TV advertisers have increased the overall frequency of scene shifts within their ads by more than 50 percent over the years. Predictably, viewers end up confused. This pursuit of attention through rapid cuts actually undermines the very pre-suasive conditions that make advertising effective. When viewers are confused, they cannot form the associative connections that pre-suasion requires.

Women perform better on math, science, and leadership tasks if assigned to rooms with cues (photos, for example) of women known to have mastered the tasks. This demonstrates how environmental priming operates at a subconscious level. The practical implication for marketers is that the context surrounding a message, whether physical environment, media placement, or preceding content, shapes receptivity to the message itself. Pre-suasion is not about changing what you say, but about changing what people are thinking about before you say it.

The mechanism involves an underappreciated characteristic of mental activity: its elements don't just fire when ready, they fire when connected. - Cialdini, Pre-Suasion

15.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Thaler & Sunstein (Nudge), Shotton (The Illusion of Choice)
15.brief:
Framing effects demonstrate that the way information is presented fundamentally changes how people respond to it. Thaler and Sunstein provide a powerful example: telling homeowners they lose $350 per year from insufficient insulation (loss frame) is more effective than telling them they could save $350 per year (gain frame). The objective information is identical, but the psychological impact is dramatically different.

Framing effects are exacerbated by the human tendency to occasionally be mindless, passive decision makers. Few of us bother to check whether reframing the decisions we face would produce a different answer. This passivity means that whoever frames the question holds enormous power over the answer, whether that framer is a marketer, a policy maker, or a journalist.

Shotton connects framing to Kahneman's WYSIATI concept: we make decisions based on the known knowns, considering only the information before us and ignoring potentially relevant factors we cannot perceive at that moment. As Kahneman writes, WYSIATI means that we use the information we have as if it is the only information. We do not consider what we might not know. This is why how you frame a choice matters enormously for marketing communications.

The practical application extends beyond simple gain/loss framing. Attribute framing (describing meat as 75% lean vs 25% fat), goal framing (emphasizing benefits of action vs costs of inaction), and risky choice framing (presenting options as gains vs losses) all produce systematic shifts in decision-making. For marketers, understanding framing is not optional; every message is framed one way or another, and the frame chosen will influence the response.

16.sources: Orlando Wood (Lemon, Advertising and the Divided Brain), System1 Group, Tim Wu (The Attention Merchants), Herbert Simon (Designing Organizations)
16.brief:
Orlando Wood examines what kind of creative work is needed by exploring the different modes of attention and how they relate to the left and right hemispheres of the brain. Drawing on psychiatrist and neuroscience researcher Iain McGilchrist, he explains that the right brain presents broad-beam attention while the left brain focuses narrow-beam attention. Broad-reach advertising that elicits an emotional response and captures broad-beam attention is how you build and maintain strong brands.

System1 analysis confirms that left-brained features are far more common in today's advertising than right-brained elements. The rise of the left-brained style of advertising has occurred in the last 10-15 years. Video campaigns ordered on skew towards number of right brain features show higher average number of very large business effects. Orlando identifies features that appeal to either the left or right brain, demonstrating that right-brain campaigns drive very large business effects through emotional engagement, characters, stories, and distinctive settings.

Tim Wu's The Attention Merchants traces the history of attention as a commodity. He documents the full potential of the business model by which attention is converted into revenue. From the 1890s through the 1920s, there arose the first means for harvesting attention on a mass scale. By the new millennium, Wu identifies a growing distaste for advertising and unprecedented willingness to pay for peace and quiet. This historical arc reveals that attention has always been the scarce resource in media, not content.

Herbert Simon, writing decades earlier, anticipated this in Designing Organizations: how much it costs, in terms of scarce attention, to receive information. Simon's insight that a wealth of information creates a poverty of attention established the theoretical foundation for understanding why attention, not information, is the binding constraint in modern marketing. Every piece of content competes not just with competitors but with the entire information environment for the consumer's finite attention.

17.sources: Romaniuk (Category Entry Points in a B2B World), Ehrenberg-Bass Institute, LinkedIn B2B Institute
17.brief:
When entering a buying situation, a category buyer first draws on existing memories to identify potential brands for purchase. These memory-generated consideration sets are the foundation of Category Entry Points (CEPs). Professor Jenni Romaniuk introduces CEPs as the cues that buyers use when thinking about a category. The CEP roadmap involves four steps to building a winning marketing strategy.

Brands need to build wider, fresher memory networks of CEPs linked to the brand. When building CEPs in marketing communications, there are three dimensions to consider: more decision makers, more CEPs per decision maker, and stronger links between CEPs and the brand. This three-dimensional approach ensures comprehensive mental availability across the entire buying center.

For B2B, the CEP framework extends to consider the professional as a person with their own desires and ambitions, such as making a splash to help get promoted. This human dimension of B2B buying is often overlooked by marketers who treat business buyers as purely rational decision-makers. The long-term message strategy needs to build brand links to different CEPs rather than just continuously focusing on only one CEP.

As the B2B Institute states, 'The most important search engine is still the one in your mind.' This insight connects CEPs directly to mental availability: the brands that win are those linked to the widest range of buying situations in memory. CEPs are not about what makes a brand different, but about what makes it relevant across the full range of category buying occasions. This reframes marketing strategy from differentiation to comprehensive mental availability.

18.brief:
Google's research identifies the messy middle of purchase behavior as a cycle of exploration and evaluation. Against a backdrop of exposure encompassing brands, products, and more, purchase triggers prompt consumers to enter a cycle of exploration and evaluation, gathering information and then narrowing it down. If the first cycle doesn't yield a definite choice, they loop back, repeating as many times as necessary.

The exploration and evaluation loop is the defining characteristic of the messy middle, and the seemingly infinite construct is key. Consumers explore their options and expand their knowledge and consideration sets, then either sequentially or simultaneously evaluate the options and narrow down their choices. This is not a neat, linear funnel but a complex, iterative process that can involve multiple loops.

Behavioral science principles can be applied at several points within the messy middle. Brands should show up at key moments of exploration and evaluation to win or protect market share. Intelligent application of behavioral science can help create a compelling proposition that appeals to shoppers at an instinctive level. Pre-existing brand affinity and price are undoubted drivers, but purchase outcomes can also be strongly influenced by messages and tactics that competing brands bring into play.

Google's research also explores optimising ads with AI and applying behavioral science in search contexts. The messy middle is where digital and traditional marketing intersect, where brand building meets performance marketing, and where behavioral science principles have their most immediate commercial impact. Brands that understand the messy middle can design touchpoints that leverage biases like social proof, authority, and scarcity at the precise moments when consumers are most susceptible to influence.

19.sources: Dooley (Brainfluence), Zaltman (How Customers Think), Barden (Decoded), Lindstrom (Buyology), Eat Your Greens
19.brief:
Neuromarketing applies neuroscience insights to marketing. Dooley explains that understanding how customers' brains work leads to better products and better marketing. People experience a neurochemical reward when they acquire new information, which is why novelty works in marketing. Implicit measures reveal different attitudes than explicit surveys.

Zaltman's research on implicit associations shows that people displayed much more positive attitudes toward particular brands and toward alcohol consumption generally when measured implicitly compared to focus groups and surveys. Response latency measures returned a different assessment of the size and composition of target markets than traditional methods. As one consensus map or thought is activated, it can stimulate another thought within that same map or even in a related map. Whenever a new thought is activated, it primes yet additional thoughts.

Barden's Decoded provides crucial quantification of implicit processing. The autopilot has a processing capacity of 11 million bits per second, compared to the pilot's severely limited capacity. The implicit system operates on the implicit level of decision making and is based on robust and accurate findings. Lindstrom's Buyology demonstrates these principles in action: subjects taste products while scanned by fMRI, revealing that brain responses to brands diverge dramatically from stated preferences.

Eat Your Greens contributes important perspective on the role of neuroscience in marketing practice. The chapters on neuroscience and marketing explore both the promise and the limitations of neuro tools, arguing that while neuroscience provides valuable insights into implicit processing, it must be combined with behavioral data and market-level evidence to be truly useful. The spreading activation model explains how brand associations work at a neurological level and why marketers must understand implicit rather than just explicit consumer responses.

20.sources: Cialdini (Influence), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing), Shotton (The Illusion of Choice)
20.brief:
Cialdini identifies commitment and consistency as a powerful principle of influence. As Harhut explains, citing Cialdini: 'Once we have made up our minds about an issue, stubborn consistency allows us a very appealing luxury: We really don't have to think hard about the issue anymore.' Maintaining consistency is easy, requiring no subsequent thought time or further analysis. This cognitive shortcut is deeply ingrained because consistency is socially valued and mentally efficient.

The general idea in sales is to pave the way for full-line distribution by starting with a small order. When a person has signed an order for your merchandise, even though the profit is so small it hardly compensates for the time and effort, he is no longer a prospect, he is a customer. This transformation of identity through small initial commitments is the engine of the consistency principle.

Shotton describes the foot-in-the-door technique: by actually creating a really small initial action, you make the first genuine step on the journey seem as easy as possible. The contrasting door-in-the-face technique is more lateral, making the genuine ask seem small by comparison. Both are two-step approaches trying to achieve the same thing: leveraging the consistency principle to increase compliance.

For digital marketing, the commitment principle explains why micro-conversions (newsletter signups, free tool usage, webinar attendance) are so valuable. Each small commitment shifts the user's self-image toward being a customer of the brand. Written commitments are more powerful than verbal ones, public commitments more powerful than private ones, and commitments that require effort more powerful than effortless ones. This hierarchy guides the design of engagement ladders.

21.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Alter & Oppenheimer
21.brief:
Cognitive ease, or fluency, is the experience of how easy something is to process mentally. Kahneman explains that the technical term for cognitive ease is fluency, citing Alter and Oppenheimer's work 'Uniting the Tribes of Fluency to Form a Metacognitive Nation.' The research reveals multiple types of fluency, all of which influence judgment: perceptual fluency (how easy something is to see), conceptual fluency (how easy it is to understand), and linguistic fluency (how easy it is to say).

When people are instructed to frown while doing a task, they actually try harder and experience greater cognitive strain. Frowning normally accompanies cognitive strain and the effect is symmetric. This embodied cognition finding demonstrates that the relationship between ease and positive evaluation runs in both directions: ease creates positive feelings, and positive physical states create a sense of ease.

Things that are easy to process feel more familiar, more true, and more likable. A sentence that was literally true but hard to process may be doubted, while a rhyming sentence feels more truthful. Words that rhyme are judged as more accurate than equivalent non-rhyming statements. This is why advertising slogans that rhyme persist across decades.

Stocks with pronounceable trading symbols (like KAR or LUNMOO) outperform those with tongue-twisting tickers like PXG or RDO. Investors believe stocks with fluent names like Emmi and Swissfirst will earn higher returns than those with clunky labels like Geberit and Ypsomed. For marketers, this means that messages, brand names, and creative content that are easy to process will be perceived as more trustworthy and appealing. Fluency is not superficial; it fundamentally shapes how information is received and evaluated.

22.sources: Wood (Advertising and the Divided Brain), Binet & Field (The Long and the Short of It), LinkedIn B2B Report, Eat Your Greens
22.brief:
Orlando Wood's analysis shows that right-brain campaigns (emotional, character-driven, story-based) drive significantly more very large business effects than left-brain campaigns (rational, information-heavy). Broad-reach advertising that elicits an emotional response and captures broad-beam attention is how you build and maintain strong brands. This finding challenges the widespread belief that rational product information is the most effective form of advertising.

Binet and Field's IPA Databank analysis confirms that emotional campaigns are more effective for long-term brand building: brand building is ultimately more effective because the effects last longer and so accumulate over time. Brand building also reduces price sensitivity and increases margins. As a result, brand building is the main driver of long-term growth and profit.

Eat Your Greens sounds an urgent warning about the contribution that our creative people make to advertising effectiveness. And the peril they, and we, are facing. As the industry shifts toward data-driven, performance-focused marketing, the creative skills that produce emotional, right-brain advertising are being undervalued and lost. This represents a threat to long-term effectiveness that goes beyond budget allocation.

The LinkedIn B2B Report extends these findings to business markets, establishing that harnessing the power of emotion is one of five key principles for effective B2B advertising. Emotional engagement is not just a B2C phenomenon. A high degree of emotional engagement was common across all successful campaigns, with the most effective ads invoking emotion in a credible way. The evidence across all sources converges: emotional advertising is more effective than rational advertising for building brands, regardless of whether the buyer is a consumer or a business professional.

23.brief:
Cialdini identifies authority as a key principle of influence. Our obedience to authority frequently takes place in a click, whirr fashion, with little or no conscious deliberation. Information from a recognized authority can provide us a valuable shortcut for deciding how to act in a situation. This automatic deference to authority evolved because following expert guidance was generally adaptive throughout human history.

Conforming to the dictates of authority figures has always had genuine practical advantages for us. Being viewed as either in authority or an authority leads to increased compliance, but the first type (merely being in charge) often generates resistance and resentment. The second type (being viewed as highly informed) avoids this problem, as people are usually willing to follow expert guidance. This distinction is critical for content marketing: thought leadership works because it establishes the author as an authority on the topic.

A communicator who does the work of collecting and then pointing to support from multiple experts will be more successful than one who settles for claiming the support of just one. This aggregation of authority is particularly powerful because it combines the authority principle with social proof. When multiple experts agree, the combined influence is greater than the sum of its parts.

In one experiment documented by Google's Decoding Decisions, college students' brains showed that decision-making parts showed less activity when receiving advice from a renowned economist, as students offloaded the burden of the decision process to the expert. This neurological evidence confirms that authority doesn't just influence which option people choose; it actually changes how they process the decision, reducing cognitive effort and bypassing careful evaluation.

24.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Shotton (The Illusion of Choice)
24.brief:
Kahneman's research reveals the peak-end rule: the global retrospective rating of an experience is well predicted by the average of the level of pain reported at the worst moment (the peak) and at the end. Duration neglect means the length of an experience has surprisingly little effect on our memory of it. These findings fundamentally challenge the assumption that every moment of customer experience matters equally.

It does not make sense to evaluate an entire life by its last moments, or to give no weight to duration in deciding which life is more desirable, yet this is what our remembering self does. The remembering self is a construction of System 2, but the distinctive features of how it evaluates episodes and lives are characteristics of our memory. We don't remember experiences as they were; we remember them as our peak-end evaluation encodes them.

Shotton draws on Milan Kundera's observation that 'memory does not make films, it makes photographs,' meaning we remember snapshots of events rather than their full duration. Our brains don't have the capacity to store every moment. Instead, we capture a fraction of what happens. This has profound implications for customer experience design: invest disproportionately in the peak moment and the ending.

For service brands and experience-based businesses, the peak-end rule provides clear strategic guidance. Rather than spreading investment evenly across every touchpoint, concentrate resources on creating an extraordinary peak moment and a memorable ending. A hotel that provides a mediocre check-in, mediocre room, but an extraordinary restaurant experience and a warm farewell gift will be remembered more positively than one that provides uniformly good but unremarkable service throughout.

25.sources: Shotton (The Illusion of Choice), Duhigg (The Power of Habit via Thinking in Bets), Duke (Thinking in Bets)
25.brief:
Habits make quick-fire decision making possible. Without habits we'd struggle to deal with the complexity of life. Habits form through the habit loop of cue, routine, and reward. Understanding this loop is essential for any marketer seeking to create lasting behavior change rather than one-time transactions.

As Annie Duke explains in Thinking in Bets, the golden rule of habit change says we don't have to give up the reward. Duhigg recognizes that respecting the habit loop means respecting the way our brain is built. Instead of trying to eliminate a habit, you can substitute a new routine while maintaining the existing cue and reward. This insight transforms habit change from willpower-dependent to system-dependent.

Shotton's research shows that if you want to encourage behaviour change, it's not enough just to boost motivation. Often, increased desire doesn't translate into behaviour change. You also need to create a cue that will prompt the desired action. Implementation intentions, effectively triggers to remind people to act, dramatically increase follow-through: in one study, 91% exercised at least once a week when given a trigger, compared to those with motivation alone.

Nationwide's 2019 campaign introduced 'Pay Day = Save Day' as a cue, reporting an eight-percentage point rise in recognition of saving importance and finishing the year with net savings balance five times forecast. Rather than create a cue from thin air, it's often better to attach the behaviour you're trying to encourage to an existing behaviour. This piggy-backing approach leverages established neural pathways rather than trying to build entirely new ones, making habit formation faster and more reliable.

26.sources: Multiple Q2 sources: Cialdini, Kahneman, Wood, Romaniuk, Google Research, Barden (Decoded), Duke (Thinking in Bets), Eat Your Greens
26.brief:
Q2 reveals how behavioral principles can be deliberately applied to engineer consumer choice. Pre-suasion (Cialdini) shows that what happens before a message determines its impact, though TV advertisers have undermined this by increasing scene shifts over 50%. Framing effects (Kahneman) demonstrate that presentation changes decisions. The attention economy (Wood, Wu, Simon) reveals that emotional, right-brain advertising drives more business effects while attention itself is the scarce resource.

Category entry points (Romaniuk) provide a systematic framework for building brand-relevant memories, with the most important search engine still being the one in the buyer's mind. The messy middle (Google) maps the exploration-evaluation loop where behavioral science principles can be applied, including AI optimization in search. Neuromarketing fundamentals show that implicit associations matter more than explicit attitudes, with the autopilot processing 11 million bits per second.

Commitment and consistency create escalating engagement through small initial actions. Fluency makes messages feel true. Emotional advertising outperforms rational approaches in both B2C and B2B, while Eat Your Greens warns of the peril facing creative effectiveness. Authority provides shortcuts for decisions, with brain scans showing literal offloading of cognitive effort to experts. The peak-end rule shows where to invest in experiences. And habit formation demonstrates that cues, not motivation, drive behavior change.

Together these tools give marketers a systematic toolkit for engineering choice at every stage of the decision journey. The golden rule of habit change (respecting how the brain is built) and the fluency heuristic (easy processing equals trust) are particularly powerful because they work with human psychology rather than against it.

27.sources: Binet & Field (Effectiveness in Context, The Long and the Short of It), IPA Databank
27.brief:
Binet and Field's analysis of the IPA Databank demonstrates that brand building is the primary driver of long-term growth and profitability. Their meta-analysis covers 996 case studies, 700 brands, 83 categories over 30 years. Effectiveness is measured in terms of effects, not prizes. This distinction is critical because prize-winning creativity and business-building creativity are not always the same thing.

Annualised ESOV efficiency relates share growth per annum to ESOV as the primary measure of efficiency. The practical implication is that if sales success is measured over a period of less than 6 months, then the metric will favour short-term communications and marketing tactics; if over longer than 6 months, then the metric will favour long-term communications and marketing. This measurement window bias systematically distorts investment decisions.

There is a growing tendency to use very short-term online metrics as primary performance measures. So the major threat in practice is that the use of short-term metrics will damage the long-term profitability of brands. This threat will increase with the movement towards real-time campaign management. Dashboard-driven marketing optimization, while appearing scientific, can actively destroy brand value by starving brand building of resources.

Brand price elasticity should be tracked: the lower the better. And strength of promotional response should be monitored: big responses are a sign of a weak brand. A brand that requires deep discounts to drive volume has weak equity. Conversely, a brand that maintains sales at full price demonstrates strong brand building ROI. These metrics provide the long-term health indicators that short-term dashboards miss entirely.
keyQuotes: If sales success is measured over less than 6 months, the metric will favour short-term tactics; if over longer than 6 months, it will favour long-term brand building. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It

28.brief:
Measuring mental availability requires tracking brand links to category entry points. Romaniuk and Sharp define mental availability metrics based on the quality and quantity of memory structures related to the brand. The key is measuring how many CEPs a brand is linked to, and how strong those links are. This requires tracking the brand's presence in consumers' memories across different buying situations.

Unlike traditional brand tracking which focuses on unaided and aided awareness, mental availability measurement captures whether a brand comes to mind in specific purchase contexts. This is a fundamentally different question: not 'do you know this brand?' but 'would you think of this brand when you need X?' The distinction between awareness and mental availability explains why some well-known brands still lose market share.

Measuring advertising's effect on mental availability will begin to provide expected benchmarks for marketers and aid development of strategies to build a brand's mental availability under conditions specific to the category. As mental availability is a competitive process, the advertising activity of competitors will also have an impact on memory, so comparing brands in the same category provides important extension.

The Distinctive Asset Grid measures brand asset fame and uniqueness, providing a systematic framework for tracking asset performance. Together with CEP measurement, this creates a comprehensive toolkit for monitoring the two dimensions of mental availability: being thought of in buying situations (CEPs) and being correctly identified when encountered (distinctive assets). Both dimensions must be tracked and managed to maintain and grow mental availability.
keyQuotes: Mental availability is the probability that a buyer will notice, recognize and/or think of a brand in buying situations, dependent on the quality and quantity of memory structures related to the brand. - Romaniuk & Sharp, Journal of Advertising Research

Brand memory is competitive: competitor advertising directly impacts your mental availability

29.sources: Phua, Hartnett, Beal, Trinh & Kennedy (Journal of Advertising Research, 2023), Ephron
29.brief:
Research published in the Journal of Advertising Research examines what happens when brands stop advertising for a year or longer. Using market share as the measure (where prior research used sales), losses were quantified as declining by 10 percent after one year, 20 percent after two years, and 28 percent after three years relative to the last advertised year, on average. These are not small numbers; they represent existential threats to brand viability.

Brand size and market share trajectory before stopping advertising affect the rate of market share loss. Larger brands with strong momentum decay more slowly, but even they are not immune to the corrosive effects of advertising cessation. Such quantification facilitates financial forecasting and portfolio decision making concerning advertising cessations. For the first time, marketers can model the cost of going dark against the cost of continued investment.

Despite an appreciation of the risks, it is still common for brands to have extended periods when they do not advertise. Brands stop advertising for various reasons including pressure of inflating earnings to avoid buyouts, competition for budget across brand portfolios, or other business requirements. The short-term financial gains from cutting advertising budgets are real but temporary, while the market share losses compound over time.

Ephron advocated that advertising needs continuity, because not being there with a message is like being out-of-stock. The research adds to the evidence that continuity over the long-term benefits brand performance. Just as a retailer would never voluntarily take products off shelves, brands should never voluntarily remove themselves from the advertising landscape. The evidence makes the cost of going dark quantifiable and the case for continuity irrefutable.

30.sources: Aggarwal et al. (GEO: Generative Engine Optimization, Princeton/IIT Delhi), Manipulating LLMs (Harvard), How to Rank in ChatGPT, Top Brand Visibility Factors, AI Citations (Yext)
30.brief:
Generative Engine Optimization is the first general optimization framework for website owners to optimize their websites for generative engines. Generative engines, in contrast to traditional search engines, remove the need to navigate to websites by directly providing a precise and comprehensive response, potentially reducing organic traffic to websites and impacting their visibility. GEO can improve the visibility of websites by up to 40% on a wide range of queries.

The research proposes visibility metrics specifically designed for generative engines. Key optimization methods include Statistics Addition (adding relevant statistics), Quotation Addition (incorporating credible quotes), and Cite Sources (including citations from reliable sources). These methods achieved 30-40% relative improvement on Position-Adjusted Word Count metrics. SEO methods such as Keyword Stuffing perform poorly in generative engines. Lower-ranked websites benefit disproportionately from GEO optimization.

Harvard research on Manipulating LLMs reveals a framework to game an LLM's recommendations in favor of a target product by inserting a strategic text sequence (STS). The research demonstrates that a product can go from not being recommended to the top recommendation in 100 iterations. This shows both the opportunity and the vulnerability in AI-driven search: brands that understand how LLMs process and recommend content can gain significant competitive advantage.

Data from How to Rank in ChatGPT provides compelling evidence: AI search visitors convert at 4.4x higher rates than traditional search visitors. ChatGPT mentions brands 3.2x more often than it provides clickable citations, suggesting that brand mentions in AI outputs may be more important than link-based SEO. This fundamentally changes the calculus of search optimization, shifting focus from ranking on a results page to being mentioned in a generated response.

31.brief:
Les Binet introduces Share of Search as a new metric: the ratio of searches for a brand to searches for all brands in the category. Share of searches correlates with market share across multiple categories tested. This metric leverages the world's biggest database of human intentions (search data). The elegance of Share of Search lies in its simplicity and accessibility: unlike SOV data, which requires expensive media spend tracking, search data is freely available.

The IPA group's research, led by Binet and joined by organizations including Google, LinkedIn, Unilever, Kantar, Mediacom, and Zenith, validates that media investment effects can be tracked through Share of Search. MyTelescope was invited to join the IPA group, contributing both data and advanced analytics. This coalition of major industry players lends significant credibility to the metric.

However, the approach has limitations: you need to be careful about brands with common words in their names (like Nutmeg, which could pick up people looking for the spice). Similarly, if a major brand has multiple offerings or too large a footprint, it could confuse the analysis. These methodological challenges require careful handling but do not invalidate the core finding.

Share of Search is particularly powerful as a leading indicator of market share changes, giving marketers early warning signals about competitive dynamics. When share of search rises, market share tends to follow. When it falls, market share typically declines. This leading indicator quality makes it invaluable for strategic planning and competitive monitoring, especially in categories where market share data is expensive or delayed.

32.sources: Lumen Research, WARC, Follett (The True Cost of Advertising Attention), Shotton (The Choice Factory)
32.brief:
Mike Follett's cross-media attention research combines attention data from TVision and Lumen to show how much visual engagement ads in different media generate and whether this extra attention is reflected in the price advertisers pay. The research reveals not only what consumers could see (what was viewable), but also what they did in fact look at (what they viewed) and, crucially, how long they looked at the ad for.

Combining these measures, including the percentage of ads that could be seen, the percentage actually viewed, and the average eyes-on dwell time, allows estimation of attentive seconds per impression. This is critical because viewable does not mean it will be viewed. The gap between viewability and actual attention varies enormously across media, creating significant pricing inefficiencies that informed media planners can exploit.

Dwell time dramatically affects recall: compared to the low dwell-time group, those who had longer exposure to ads were six times more likely to recall the ad, four times more likely to remember details, and fourteen times more likely to correctly remember the brand. These multipliers demonstrate that attention quality, not just attention quantity, drives advertising effectiveness.

The distinction between viewability and actual attention is fundamental for media planning. Media that delivers high viewability but low actual attention may be overpriced relative to its true impact. Conversely, media with lower viewability metrics but higher actual attention (longer dwell times when viewed) may deliver superior value. This reframes media evaluation from crude impression counting to attention-quality assessment, potentially reshaping media budgets significantly.

33.sources: Sharp (How Brands Grow), Ehrenberg-Bass Institute, DJ 50 Years on
33.brief:
The Law of Double Jeopardy, tested extensively over fifty years, shows that smaller brands suffer twice: they have fewer buyers AND those buyers are slightly less loyal. As Sharp demonstrates with shampoo data, smaller brands suffer from only slightly lower loyalty. The primary difference between big and small brands is penetration (number of buyers), not loyalty (purchase frequency per buyer).

Brands grow primarily by increasing their market penetration. The law has been extensively tested over thirty-five years or more and provides a key to how brands grow. The mathematical underpinning is described in the DJ 50 Years on paper through the w(1-b) approximation, which provides a precise model for the double jeopardy relationship between penetration and purchase frequency.

When Double Jeopardy constrains choice behaviour, brand share growth depends on substantially increasing the size of the customer base rather than managing customer loyalty. Jim Nyce, previously Insights Director at Kraft, describes this as 'swimming downstream.' Try as one might, if you are successful in gaining sales it's unlikely you'll break the double jeopardy law. And the IPA Effectiveness Awards results remind us that it is a much better strategy to go with the law than against it.

Double jeopardy applies across categories from shampoo to ready-mix concrete, from radio stations to political parties. This universality is what makes it a law rather than a tendency. The practical implication is revolutionary: marketers should focus on customer acquisition through broad reach rather than customer retention through loyalty programs. The evidence consistently shows that growth comes from getting more buyers, not from getting existing buyers to buy more.

34.sources: Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, Ad Spending: Maintaining Market Share
34.brief:
Advertising elasticity is the ratio of the proportional increase in sales to the proportional increase in advertising. The response to advertising typically shows diminishing marginal returns: each additional exposure produces less effect than the last. Understanding this curve is essential for efficient budget allocation.

When diminishing returns occur, the most cost-effective number of exposures (effective frequency) is one per person and it is best to use a continuous schedule that spreads advertising across the target population as widely as possible. This finding directly contradicts the traditional media planning approach of building frequency against a narrow target, which wastes budget on exposures that produce diminishing returns.

Advertising elasticity is high for new brands but lower for established ones. Many long-established brands have built a useful track record of experience with varying levels of advertising pressure, and in many cases, econometric studies have produced a specific advertising elasticity. This body of evidence enables precise calibration of advertising investment for established brands.

The advertising elasticity of most brands is low, which means competitors need not fear an opportunistic advertising increase too much. Even if a brand goes it alone and reduces advertising, sales may not suffer markedly in the short term, though long-term effects will accumulate. This creates a dangerous temptation: cutting advertising budgets shows no immediate penalty but steadily erodes brand health. The asymmetry between short-term cost savings and long-term brand decay makes advertising cuts appear rational in the short term while being destructive in the long term.

35.brief:
The LinkedIn B2B Institute, drawing on Ehrenberg-Bass research, highlights that at any given time approximately 95% of potential buyers are out-of-market, not actively looking to buy. Only about 5% are in-market at any moment. This has profound implications for both B2B and B2C marketing strategy.

Over 65% of B2B marketers believe that businesses grow by increasing loyalty, not customer acquisition, but the evidence contradicts this. This discrepancy presents B2B marketers with a precious, career-making opportunity: to be both right and contrarian. When the majority is wrong, those who follow the evidence gain disproportionate competitive advantage.

The Five Principles of Growth for B2B marketing include investing in share of voice, balancing brand and activation, maximizing reach, maximizing mental availability, and harnessing the power of emotion. Only 52% of B2B marketers believe reach is a strong predictor of advertising success. Those B2B marketers who are brave enough to reject consensus opinion and bet big on evidence-based principles will outperform their competition.

The 95-5 rule explains why brand building is essential: if you only target the 5% currently in-market, you miss the 95% who will enter the market in coming months and years. Brand building creates mental availability among future buyers so that when they do enter the market, your brand is already in their consideration set. Performance marketing captures demand that brand building creates. Without brand building, the pool of demand available for performance marketing steadily shrinks.

36.sources: Sharp (How Brands Grow), Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, Ephron
36.brief:
The reach vs frequency debate centers on whether it's better to reach more people fewer times or fewer people more times. The evidence from Sharp and Ehrenberg-Bass strongly favors maximizing reach. This conclusion follows directly from diminishing marginal returns and the double jeopardy law.

Advertising response follows diminishing marginal returns: each additional exposure produces less effect than the last, making the most cost-effective number of exposures one per person. It is best to use a continuous schedule that spreads the advertising across the target population as widely as possible. In this way, more people are reached, maximizing the return on advertising investment.

Ephron advocated for weekly reach planning, which would mean being on air for more weeks at a lower weight. This shelf-space advertising model argues that advertising needs continuity because not being there with a message is like being out-of-stock. The metaphor is powerful: just as empty shelf space represents lost sales opportunities, advertising gaps represent lost opportunities to influence potential buyers.

The implication is clear: broad reach with lower frequency is more efficient than narrow reach with high frequency, particularly for brand building. Combined with the 95-5 rule (95% of potential buyers are out-of-market at any time), maximizing reach ensures that the brand message reaches as many future buyers as possible. The traditional media planning obsession with building frequency against a narrow target actively works against the evidence on how brands grow.

37.sources: Binet & Field (IPA Studies, The Long and the Short of It), Media in Focus, Kahneman (Noise)
37.brief:
Binet and Field document a growing marketing effectiveness crisis driven by short-termism. There is a growing tendency to use very short-term online metrics as primary performance measures. The major threat is that the use of short-term metrics will damage the long-term profitability of brands. This threat will increase with the movement towards real-time campaign management and its inevitable focus on short-term results.

To an alarming degree, marketing appears to be sleepwalking towards a precipice, and there is an urgent need for long-term metrics to reassert their importance. The IPA Databank shows that if advertising effects decay in a non-exponential manner, it is almost impossible to predict the long-term sales effects of marketing activity from short-term responses. This raises serious questions about the reliability of short-term optimization.

Kahneman's Noise adds a critical dimension to the effectiveness crisis. Noise is variability in judgments that should be identical. If judgments vary for no good reason, then Noise is detrimental. Applied to marketing measurement, this means that inconsistency in how marketing effectiveness is evaluated, across teams, time periods, and methodologies, introduces systematic error that compounds the short-termism problem. When measurement itself is noisy, optimizing against that measurement creates the illusion of improvement while potentially destroying value.

Media in Focus confirms that mass marketing still works, tight targeting has limitations, and the digital era requires new approaches to measuring effectiveness. The crisis is not that marketing doesn't work; it's that the industry has adopted measurement systems that systematically undervalue what works (brand building) while overvaluing what is easily measured (short-term activation).

38.sources: Binet & Field (Effectiveness in Context), IPA Databank analysis, Duke (Thinking in Bets), Kay & King (Radical Uncertainty)
38.brief:
Attribution modeling faces fundamental challenges in accurately measuring marketing's contribution to business results. Binet and Field's work in Effectiveness in Context reveals that the migration from premium to value pricing is partly driven by brands focusing more on volume than pricing, a consequence of attribution models that favor measurable short-term activation over harder-to-measure brand building.

If sales success is measured over a period of less than 6 months, the metric will favour short-term communications; if over longer than 6 months, it will favour long-term brand building. The implication is that most attribution models, which operate on short timeframes, systematically undervalue brand building. This creates a vicious cycle where budgets shift toward easily measurable activation, weakening brands over time.

Annie Duke's Thinking in Bets provides a crucial insight into attribution bias: if the outcome is known, it will bias the assessment of decision quality to align with the outcome quality. This resulting (judging decisions by their outcomes rather than their process) plagues marketing attribution. Good marketing decisions that happen to produce poor short-term results are judged as failures, while poor decisions that produce lucky short-term results are celebrated.

Kay and King's Radical Uncertainty deepens the challenge: probabilistic estimates were unhelpful for understanding unique, complex situations like marketing campaigns. Marketing attribution attempts to apply probabilistic thinking to situations that are fundamentally uncertain, not merely risky. The difference matters: risk can be calculated, uncertainty cannot. This means that attribution models provide a false sense of precision that can be more dangerous than acknowledging uncertainty honestly.

39.sources: Multiple Q3 sources: Binet & Field, Romaniuk, Ehrenberg-Bass, Lumen, GEO Research, Kahneman (Noise), Duke (Thinking in Bets), Harvard LLM Research
39.brief:
Q3 establishes the evidence base for marketing effectiveness and exposes the measurement crisis threatening it. Brand building ROI is real but only visible over 6+ month timeframes (Binet & Field). Mental availability metrics provide better tracking than traditional awareness measures (Romaniuk). Brands that go dark lose 10% market share per year (Phua et al.). The evidence for continuity is now irrefutable.

GEO represents the next frontier of visibility optimization for AI-driven search, where AI visitors convert at 4.4x higher rates and LLMs can be manipulated through strategic text sequences (Harvard). Share of Search provides a freely available leading indicator of market share. Attention quality, not just viewability, determines advertising impact, with three seconds producing 14x brand attribution (Lumen).

Double jeopardy confirms growth comes from penetration, with the w(1-b) approximation providing mathematical precision. Advertising elasticity shows diminishing returns favor reach over frequency. The 95-5 rule means 95% of potential buyers are out-of-market, making brand building essential for future demand creation. Reach consistently outperforms frequency.

The marketing effectiveness crisis, driven by short-term metrics and flawed attribution, is compounded by Noise (Kahneman) in measurement and resulting (Duke) in evaluation. Radical Uncertainty challenges the very premise of probabilistic attribution. The solution requires measuring what matters over the timeframes that matter, while acknowledging that some marketing effects resist precise measurement. The industry must embrace appropriate uncertainty rather than false precision.

40.sources: Sutherland (Alchemy), Storr (The Status Game), Stengel (Branding that Means Business)
40.brief:
Rory Sutherland's Alchemy argues that the opposite of a good idea can be a good idea. He introduces the concept of psycho-logic, which operates differently from conventional logic. Sutherland observes that in business, we've allowed the administrative cast to take over by dismissing trivial-seeming creative decisions. Yet in the success of a business, making it green can be more important than capacity planning.

He describes the IKEA effect through Betty Crocker: psychologists believed that doing a little more work made women feel less guilty while still saving time, making just enough effort to give the sense of having contributed to the creation. Adding consumer effort increases someone's estimation of value. A 200 pound dress reduced to 75 pounds is fine, but women may not feel happy wearing a 75 pound dress to a wedding. This reveals the gap between economic logic and psychological reality.

Will Storr's The Status Game adds depth to understanding irrational consumer behavior. For leaders, it's perhaps more critical to show zeal on behalf of the game. Brands that demonstrate passionate commitment to their values and community create status games that consumers want to participate in. This connects to Sutherland's psycho-logic: brands succeed not by offering the best rational value proposition but by creating psychological value through identity, belonging, and status.

Stengel's Branding that Means Business asks the fundamental question: What is all this stuff for? What's the deepest value that humans can derive? Economic logic is an attempt to create a psychology-free model of human behaviour based on presumptions of rationality, but it can be a very costly mistake. Not only can a rational approach to pricing be wrong, it can be catastrophically wrong. The alchemy lies in understanding that human value is created through meaning, not just utility.
